text.p: Following are some of the main stories in Dutch newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
FINANCIEELE DAGBLAD
- Parliamentary majority emerging in favour of abolishing wealth tax. (p1)
- Retailer Vendex has fresh doubts about sale of 36 pct stake in Koninklijke Bijenkorf Beheer (KBB) chainstore. (p1)
- Brewer Bavaria to expand share capital and change status from limited company to public limited company. (p1)
- EOE Options Exchange books record turnover of 352,500 contracts on Friday. (p1)
- Stork buys back 50 pct stake in Stork Ketels, held by Deutsche Babcock; Ketels restructuring to follow. (p3)
- Mould maker Axxicon books Dfl 1.7 million Q3 net; maintains earlier full year profit forecast. (p3)
- Dutch seaports to coordinate activities and study possibilties of increasing cooperation. (p4)
- ABN AMRO bank bids for Hungary's Magyar Hitel Bank. (p4)
DE VOLKSKRANT
- PSV Eindhoven go top of league with thumping 7-2 win over Feyenoord. (p1)
- With many foreign nationals and multi-language skills, the Netherlands is the perfect place to establish call-centres, telephone bases for 24-hour operations.. (p2)
- Spar supermarket wants to set up convenience shops at petrol stations. (p2)
- Fokker receivers sell 50 pct stake in FSC training centre to Maastricht Airport. (p2)
DE TELEGRAAF
- Three Dutch tourists killed in coach crash in France. (p1)
- Food firm Nutricia stops using genetically-manipulated soybeans in baby foods. (p13)
- Packagaging group Van Leer to start consumer packaging operation in Turkey. (p13)
- Golden Florin starts Internet site for options investors. (p13)
TROUW
- Poor turnout disappoints organisers of Amsterdam multimedia fair Emotion '96.
ALGEMEEN DAGBLAD
- Dutch petrol stations along German and Belgian borders plan action against cabinet plans for petrol duty hike. (p5)
- HCG, unit of builder HBG, to shed 88 of 1460 jobs in restructuring. (p11)
